WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT: b'I think, in my opinion, it\'s because the systems that led to our anxiety haven\'t changed. Precarious housing, shitty jobs, shitty people doing shitty things to other people. Lack of resources, lack of support and caring communities. We\'re expected to solve our feelings from within, as if external factors can be ignored or "overcome".'

Perhaps it\'s what you\'re experiencing too.'

WRITING.TITLE: b'Two steps forward, one step back'
WRITING.TEXT:
b"I know healing isn't linear, and I'm trying to be really kind to myself right now, but I'm still feeling disappointed in myself.

My physical anxiety symptoms are largely of the stomach and digestive variety. I've made huge progress with therapy, and honestly most days I can get through work and life just fine with my coping mechanisms, and if worst comes to worst, I'll take Pepto or something.

I had a terrible night's sleep last night so I was already primed to not want to go to work. But I got ready to go, and headed out the door. About halfway there I had that familiar 'uh oh' feeling in my stomach. And I gave in and just decided to turn around and go home. Now that I'm home I know I could have made it fine at work today, and I'm feeling like I gave in to my anxiety.

I know this is a minor setback, but I'm feeling disappointed and bummed out. How have you encouraged yourself after you've had a set back? How do you exercise kindness to yourself when you feel you've let yourself down? Thanks for reading my little rant \xe2\x99\xa5\xef\xb8\x8f"

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT: b'Before we started dating we had been friends for a while, and would often tell each other "love you!" in a friend way. Once we started dating, we decided that we didn\'t want to throw around the "I love yous" carelessly like maybe we\'d done when we were friends.\n\nIt was maybe less than a week before they we said "I love you" to each other again. Everytime we parted ways it felt almost painful to not say "I love you". We\'ve been together nearly 11 years now.'

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT: b'For me, and I think for others too, anxiety is a kind of "out of control" coping mechanism. For example, I catastrophise, which I realise is my brains\' broken way of "protecting me" from a terrible scenario. And while I\'ve read a lot about how to deal with anxiety in the moment or when it\'s happening, I think there are so many complex and unique scenarios that can lead people to experience it, that it\'s complicated and it would be remiss to assign a "one size fits all" solution to the treatment of it.'

WRITING.TEXT: b"I'm Canadian and doing the French language track in Duo. I use an app called Mauril. It helps with my listening comprehension, specifically listening to French Canadian, since it is quite different sounding that standard French. Mauril doesn't really help with grammar or spelling, but you watch these little video clips, listen, and answer questions about the video's content."

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT: b"I've been there... And while I don't have any particular advice, I remember when I had a glimmer of it coming back. I was at the beach (I didn't want to be there, positive something terrible would happen while I was there). But I just decided to recline in my chair and close my eyes. And something about the water sounds and the breeze just made me forget about everything, just for a little while, but it was the first glimpse of joy I'd experienced in a long time. I guess my advice is to do things that used to bring you joy, even if you really really don't want to do them. And it won't happen right away, it takes practice, but I'm hopeful you'll get there."

Knowing I have to get up for in-person work the next day inevitably causes me to have a bad night's sleep, which results in anxiety about my body, an anxious stomach, etc..."

WRITING.TITLE: b"I'm vegetarian, I love sandwiches, and hate tomatoes. Suggestions?"
WRITING.TEXT:
b'I've been vegetarian for about 10 years, and I miss good, hearty sandwiches. 

I've hated tomatoes for my entire life. Cooked tomatoes are fine. Love tomato sauce, salsa is wonderful. But something about sliced raw tomato is revolting to my taste buds.  I WANT to like them, and I'll often put them on a sandwich thinking "maybe THIS TIME it will be good" but no. I end up regretting my decision every time. 

I feel like nearly all good vegetarian sandwiches I see include tomato, and they often feel "empty" without. Do any of you good folks have any suggestions or ideas for meatless sandwiches that feel substantial and hearty without tomato?'

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT: b'I can\'t say that the vertigo I experienced was necessarily anxiety-related (although maybe it was and I wasn\'t aware of that at the time). When I\'ve experienced vertigo it was always when I was up high (stairs looking down, hiking along a cliff, etc). I\'ve experienced dizziness in the usual ways - standing up too fast, spinning around in a chair... I get dizzy spells when I\'m anxious, and they\'re more like "standing up too fast" kind of feelings. I find it hard to necessarily pinpoint specific triggers - to be honest it almost feels like I\'m starting to disassociate when it happens, so it\'s like a little warning sign to get grounded back in reality.'

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT:
b'I started by telling myself I could have a "dedicated worry time" - let's say, 15 minutes starting at 5:30 when I'm done work (just an example). When I felt something in my body that I instantly wanted to Google, I'd just tell myself "if it's still bothering me when 5:30 rolls around, I can deal with it then, but for now I'm going to keep doing what I was doing". 
First, it's not an easy habit to break. I'd find myself subconsciously Googling before I had a chance to stop. Just put the phone down or close the browser as soon as you notice.
It didn't take long before I noticed a marked difference in lower anxiety in the moments after I had the urge to Google but didn't follow through. Anxiety is a wave. Google adds more water; not Googling helps reduce the size of the wave and gets you through it faster.
Eventually it got to a point that when I got to my "dedicated worry time" I didn't care anymore. Most times I became distracted and totally forgot about the symptoms, and basically lost interest in what Google had to say.
It definitely took practice and dedication to get there, and recovery is never linear, but I feel much better now that I did before. I hope the same for you :)'

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT: b"This was entirely my own doing. I was on a flight home from Athens, Greece, to Toronto, Canada. My first solo trip abroad. I was absolutely exhausted. I guess we flew north for a bit before going west, because the last thing I remembered was looking out the window over the snow -covered Alps below us. I fell asleep, and dreamt that the plane went down and we crashed into the snowy mountains. I woke up sobbing absolutely sure that I'd just survived the plane crash and was in straight up survival mode and panicking."

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT: b"Honestly I know this probably isn't a great answer, but when this happens to me, I just begrudgingly accept it. Like, it's happened before, it'll probably happen again, and once it's time for me to get ready for work there's nothing else I can do about it . I know what to expect from my body and I know I just have to ride it out. It won't kill me, or even really hurt me, even though it's uncomfortable and unpleasant. Just try to take care of yourself in ways that you can - eat enough, get up and move around when you can, find little things that maybe make you smile throughout the day. Good luck :)"

I know you love him, but I'm not sure that someone who loves you back would treat your dietary restrictions as this much of a deal breaker."

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT:
b'Yeah, and it came from two different behaviours on their part.

First, my mother is from a family of chronically nervous people. For ex, If I'm taking a trip, I have to keep her posted at regular intervals. Once, I happened to stop to use the bathroom and left my phone in the car. When I got back to my phone I had texts, missed calls, and voicemails from her freaking out.

My family also loves to comment on how good the health of other people is. "She's in her 90s and isn't on any medication!" "He cured himself from cancer through food!" "No wonder he has *health condition*! He does *random arbitrary thing*!"

I feel like I was set up to be chronically nervous and somehow think that even a cold was a moral failing (health is obviously not a moral failing).'

WRITING.TEXT: b"I definitely experience a correlation between anxiety and acid reflux. Obviously if it's particularly disruptive for you, you should speak with a doctor. Also, I don't know what you're gender is, but for me, I will sometimes get TERRIBLE nighttime heartburn as a PMS symptom.\n\nHeartburn and acid reflux are definitely uncomfortable and scary, but if it only happens from time to time, it's probably nothing to be too concerned about :)"

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT:
b'For sure! There are some worksheets available for free that I've found helpful, and were recommended by my therapist: https://www.cci.health.wa.gov.au/Resources/Looking-After-Yourself/Health-Anxiety

I've recently started trying the DARE app after seeing a lot of positive reviews of it online. There's a free version, and a paid version, but I think you might be able to get 2 weeks free. So far I like it, but there's a lot of meditation and "being in your body", which I realize might be hard for people just beginning to tackle their health anxiety.

Wishing you the best \xe2\x99\xa5\xef\xb8\x8f'

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT: b"Echoing what a lot of other people have said, there are definitely a few avenues you can pursue yourself, without a therapist, to help with your anxiety (ie CBT). And in my experience doing that sort of hard work on my own has been really helpful. I will also say, though that therapies like CBT look at treating the anxiety in the moment, and to reduce the distress going forward. These therapies don't deal with the root cause of your anxiety. If you're interested in uncovering some of those root causes and digging deeper into potential traumas, you should seek out a therapist who can provide a safe space for you to do so. Best of luck [heart emoticon]"

WRITING.TITLE: b' '

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT: b"When I was having similar issues I'd put on a favorite podcast to help me fall asleep. I chose one that I knew the content would be light and not stressful,. probably something I'd already listened to. That way I could focus all my energy on listening to that instead of my internal monologue. I'd put a sleep timer into the podcast and usually I'd be asleep after a little while."

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT: b"All great tips!! And I *cannot* stress enough how important it is to not Google things. I once learned of an illness an acquaintance had acquired, Googled it, and in spite of never having heard of it before suddenly became convinced that I too might have it. Don't Google anything health related, even if it's not about you."

WRITING.TEXT:
b"To be honest I had only planned on just seeing a massage therapist, but the clinic I contacted decided to set me up with physio first, which I think was the right call. I decided to do this on my own, without my family doc or without a referral.

Stretches and exercises recommended to me:
Standing rows with a resistance band
Open book stretch
Thoracic spine mobilization with foam roller (be gentle and support your neck!!!)
Chin tuck exercise (again, be gentle)
Child's pose

This is all in addition to some neck and spine alignments that the physiotherapist has also done. Hope some of these are helpful for you!!!"

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT: b"For me, I think it's kind of complex and not just a single incident.\n\nI was born with a super rare skin condition, which is very manageable and doesn't affect me much now as an adult, but I experienced medical trauma around it when I was a kid. So now it has manifest as this fear that I'll be left vulnerable in the hands of medical professionals, only to have them leave me feeling like a human unworthy of care. But in my fear of developing any kind of illness, I just started hyperfixating on any physical symptoms, thus perpetuating this very frustrating cycle of wanting to avoid doctors, but also seeking validation from them that my body is fine. (And I am fine, and I've gotten quiet good at managing my anxiety, and am working on untangling my trauma with a good therapist)."

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT: b'Reading you story feels like I\'m reading my own story.  My mother has been antivaxx since I was a kid, and I was super proud to have my first 2 COVID vaccines without any issue. 2 days after my 3rd shot I had one of the worst anxiety attacks of my life. Everything you\'ve described, I experienced after that panic attack.\n\nI\'ve had health anxiety since I was a kid, and this has caused a "flare-up" of sorts. I\'m fortunate and thankful for having a great therapist. I\'ll echo what some other folks in this thread has mentioned about mindfulness, deep breathing, exercise, etc... But also be kind to yourself. We are collectively living through a pandemic, in which we\'ve been actively self-monitoring our bodies obsessively for at least 2 years. Breaking those behaviours is so hard!! And some of us have family members actively making this pandemic even harder for us. You\'re stronger than you know, and you\'ve got this. :)'

b"Yes, I definitely know what you mean about the physical symptoms lasting longer than the anxiety itself. I also recognize that there are times when just focusing on the physical symptom can make it feel worse, so when I notice myself doing that I just try to shift the focus on my body to a random body part (like my ankle or something). WRITING.TITLE: b'nighttime heart palpitations :('
WRITING.TEXT:
b"I've occasionally had heart palpitations in the past. They've almost always been a one-and-done. Like I might have one in the evening and be fine for days or weeks after. They're freaky, but my doctor has reassured me they're likely stress related and an EKG didn't return anything abnormal.

Last night I woke up at 2:30 from a palpitation, and I had 2 or 3 more after that between then and 5am. I barely slept at all. I called Telehealth, and since I didn't have any other symptoms the nurse just suggested I self monitor myself but that there wasn't any need to go to the hospital. I plan to go see my doctor this weekend.

The problem is, I'm now so so exhausted, but I'm too scared to sleep. I don't want that to happen again, but I know the more I stress about it the more likely it is. I'm so tired but I can't stop hyperfocusing. I think I just need some validation and reassurance right now, that this is something I'll get through, and that I'll have a good night's sleep again soon."

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT:
b"Firstly, this is such a big step and you should be proud!!

Some advice, 1) sometimes you won't 'click' with your therapist, and it's okay to seek out someone else who you can work better with. 2) healing isn't linear, so if you've had some good days, it's okay to have some really crappy days too. Don't get discouraged. 3) take notes before and after your session, of things you'd like to talk about during the session, and important things you took out of the session at the end. 4) be open to feeling weird, or silly, or uncomfortable.

Best of luck on your journey!"

WRITING.TITLE: b'Does everyone else wonder how the rest of the world functions WITHOUT health anxiety?'
WRITING.TEXT: b"Sometimes I wonder to myself, how do people exist in the world not constantly worried about their heart, or lungs, or any other thing happening in their body...  does anyone else ever think about this, or similar? How do you feel about that, because it often feels me with mixed feelings, often envy and hope.\n\nEven though I have gone through a lot of my life not obsessing over my health anxiety, when I'm in the throes of an anxious brain it seems so unbelievable to me that people *don't* constantly think about their health and prepare for the worst, but when I share my experience with other people they really don't seem to get it."

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT: b"I'm honestly not entirely sure yet... I don't plan on seeing them for a long time after this incident. And whenever I do see them, it will only be after I have a serious conversation with them about upsetting that was for me. I guess making my boundaries known is easy, it's holding those boundaries that is hard."

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT:
b"Oh boy, have I been in need of a place to vent...

My parents are Q-adjacent, unvaxxed, are convinced it's just the flu, etc...

My grandmother's health had been declining recently, and my mom was her primary care giver. She told me 2 weeks ago that if I wanted to say goodbye, I should go. It's about a 6.5 hour drive, and I stayed with my parents for the weekend I was there. I had a super candid conversation with my parents about how bad my health anxiety has been since the omicron wave. I made it super clear I do not want to become ill. The conversation actually left me feeling good - like they were actually listening to my concerns and didn't dismiss them.

Last week my grandma died. My mom asked for my support and help to clean out her apartment. I made the long drive back. The night I arrived my dad casually mentioned he hadn't been going out for walks because he wasn't feeling well. I noticed some cough and cold medicine in their bathroom and asked about it. Apparently my mom has also had a cough for some time. I asked why they didn't tell me that they were both feeling ill. My mom's response was that she didn't want to tell me because she knew I wouldn't have gone if I'd known they were sick. 

That comment left me totally stunned. I can't believe after our conversation the week prior that they'd wilfully withhold that information from me. I am so angry, and so hurt. I don't know if they have COVID. I have since done a rapid test and it came back negative so I'm a bit hopeful. But still, so so angry. The selfishness is astounding."

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT: b"I'm in Canada. When I was a baby I had a prescription ointment with an antibiotic mixed in. Now, as an adult I just use Aveeno with shea butter, no medicines or prescriptions."

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT: b'In addition to this, I\'d also add that when someone is talking through something I find it helpful to ask "would you like my input or thoughts, or would you prefer if I just listen right now?"'

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT: b"I'm a young woman and enjoy going for solo camping trips. A few years ago I wanted to get one last trip in before it got too cold, so headed out for one last camping trip. I went to a conservation area where there was no cell reception, that's often popular in the summer but quiet in the colder, wet months. Before arriving I had mentally chosen a spot near the river. When I arrived it was quiet, but as I got closer and closer to my desired spot I passed a group of 6 belligerently drunk dudes, camped right near when I had planned on being. They were clearly eyeing me as I hiked past. I was tired by this point, but I kept going to try to find as secluded a spot as far away from them as I could, but I didn't have a great night's sleep after that."

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT:
b'I use a couple strategies that might be helpful for you-

Distractions - can I do something that is normally calming for me (video game, conversation with a friend about something unrelated to the anxiety, a crafting project or other hobby), and then come back and reassess the feeling later? If I can forgot about it for a bit while I'm doing the thing, then there's a good chance it's anxiety.

Triggers - did I see or hear something that may have trigger this feeling? For example, I know that seeing a fictional character in a tv show have a stroke triggered something in me a few weeks ago.

Situation - was I in a physical situation that caused this physical sensations? For example, it's cold where I live so I bundle up, which can sometimes leave me feeling constricted around the neck and chest. I know that once I get inside I can take off the layers and the feeling will go away. Or if I have a pain in my back, maybe it's just because I slept super weird last night and not something terrible.

These things don't automatically make the anxiety go away, but they help me gain some perspective and at least "observe" me feelings.

I hope you find some rest through what you're going through.'

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT:
b"Hello! I also suffer from pretty severe health anxiety. I've had 3 doses of COVID vaccines, and don't regret it for a second. After my 2nd and 3rd, I had some pretty swollen lymph nodes, which I know can be a pretty big health anxiety trigger for some folks -- that'll go away in a few days.

It sounds like the anxiety you experiences after your first shot was exhausting, and I'm really sorry you went through that for so long. Remind yourself of the thoughts and feelings that are real/true, and which are false. Prepare some healthy distractions that bring you joy or peace to help occupy your mind in the days following your vaccine.

While I will admit to having had some anxiety about the vaccines (my parents are anti vaxxers and I've been steeped in that rhetoric), the vaccine anxiety was much much less than the anxiety that would surely result if I actually got COVID without some level of protection. 

Most importantly, take care of yourself, in every way you need to."

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT: b'It does help, thank you :)\n\nThe silly thing is, as I engage in checking and reassuring behaviours, I literally can\'t feel a thing. No bumps, no tender spots no matter how hard I push, just, the occasional feeling that "something is different". Rational brain vs irrational brain is such a battle.'

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT: b"About 3 weeks ago I noticed some soreness around my left breast. My doctor didn't think it was anything to be concerned about, heart and lungs sound good. Nothing abnormal in an x-ray. But I'm still hyperfocused on that part of my body. If it's anything, it's probably just achey muscles from holding so much tension...but I just woke up this morning feeling kind of sore again, and that reminder is just a lousy way for me to start my day."

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT: b"Yes, I've been trying to get myself to exercise more. I go for hikes pretty frequently, but when I'm just slouched in an office chair all day I'm not doing my body any favours. Thank you for the reply, take care :)"

WRITING.TITLE: b'Folks with health anxiety - how do you quiet the nagging feeling that something is wrong?'
WRITING.TEXT:
b"When logically you know that there's *probably* nothing terribly bad happening in your body, but some twitch or weird muscle feeling is enough to send you spiraling, how do you deal?

I honestly don't remember what happened first -- I had a really bad panic attack about 3 weeks ago, and around the same time I noticed that my left breast was feeling achey. The ache in my chest exacerbated the anxiety, and it became this feedback loop. It seems like wearing a bra makes the soreness worse. My doctor found nothing wrong with my heart or lungs, and an x-ray didn't show anything out of the ordinary. Logically, it's probably the anxiety roller coaster that I've been on causing the weird chest feeling, combined with wearing a constricting bra, which makes it worse. But as soon as I feel anything in my chest now, I just mentally spiral out.

I've got my usual anxiety coping skills, and I have a therapist who is helpful. But I'm exhausted by having what are probably normal or explainable feelings in my body send me absolutely reeling. Has anyone else found solutions to stopping the catastrophizing caused by what you're feeling in your body?"

b"My partner and I have lived together about 5 years (together for nearly 10) and we sleep in separate beds. Edit: typo"

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT:
b"My partner and I are attempting to save for a downpayment, but that feels increasingly out of grasp.

We live in a very mediocre apartment with known infestation issues (thankfully our unit has been mostly spared the worst). We don't own a vehicle, and walk or bike whenever possible. We live pretty frugally in an attempt to save, and we both have decent jobs. My job provides me with a pension and health benefits thankfully.

It feels like our desires are so mundane. A car would be nice. We'd like to adopt a dog. I'd like to not have to live in a small apartment anymore, and maybe buy clothes for myself more than once per year. That's all, simple things I'd like to not have to worry about.

It feels like we have so little right now, and no more things we can really cut out in an attempt to save even more. We're just kind of...stuck."

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT:
b"I can relate to how you're feeling.

A couple weeks ago I was scrolling twitter when I saw a screen shot of a fairly prominent alt-right figure in Canada making a claim that was false and frankly easy to disprove. Non the less I felt pretty angry about it, mostly knowing how easy it is to post falsehoods and that people, my mom included, believe it.

I spoke a bit to my therapist about how I was feeling a lot of anger and she explained that anger is a secondary emotion, usually the result of sadness and/or anxiety, and our needs in dealing with those not being met. That really resonated with me. I'm sad for losing my mom, and I feel helpless, and I'm anxious whenever I'm around her.

I'm sorry you're feeling depressed, and I hope you have other people in your life you can go to for support. I don't think that what you're feeling is unusual or out of line with what you're going through. I hope you find some peace."

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT: b"That's really good to know, thanks! That's not who I called, but I don't remember seeing them come up in  my online searches. I'll be sure to keep them in mind!"

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT: b'I took quite a few courses during my undergrad on political and cultural theory, so I ended up with very leftist texts on my shelves, notably Marx and Nietzsche, and my mom was SO concerned about that I was becoming a Communist or something.\n\nAnd now she\'s the one reading the Epoch Times and telling me Alex Jones "made some good points".'

WRITING.TITLE: b'Emergency orthodontics'
WRITING.TEXT:
b"On this lovely Friday afternoon heading into a long weekend, the permanent retainer that was put in 13 years ago after my braces came off, has snapped.

The retainer is still partially attached to a couple teeth, no pain, but just sliding around a bit. I'm mostly worried it'll come out entirely when I'm eating or sleeping.

I went to an emergency dentist, but he wouldn't touch it, and instead told me I'd have to see an orthodontist. My original orthodontist is in Sudbury, so not super accessible.

I did call a couple places (places on Glasgow, Bridgeport, and Fairway) but a lot of orthodontic offices aren't taking emergency patients since they're backed up with regular patients.

Any suggestions of places I can try? I'm losing hope for getting this taken care of today, but hopefully early next week.

Thanks!"

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT: b"You're very patient, and this is very encouraging. Thanks for sharing, and best of luck to you."

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT:
b"Thanks for the thoughtful reply! 

Some additional context - I'm queer, my partner is trans. I'm nervous that she's going to adopt some of the beliefs that these publications peddle about people like me, so I'm just nervous that I might learn something I don't want to know.

Additionally, I don't have any siblings and my mom doesn't really have many friends, so I don't have a ton of back-up support. My therapist has been helpful in figuring how and what to say, and why, when I do talk with her."

WRITING.TITLE: b'So glad I found this Reddit - my mom is deep into conspiracy theories'
WRITING.TEXT:
b"I'm not sure if she knows anything about Q, but I saw several editions of the Epoch Times laying around her house and there's enough overlap there that I got pretty concerned...

My mom has been into conspiracy theories for a while. When I was in high school she started on vaccines. It's since grown to include things as mundane as MSG and the moon landing, to 9/11, various things about Hillary Clinton (I don't even live in the U.S.). She tried to convince me that I shouldn't worry about coronavirus because chloroquine would cure me. She's completely stopped trying to talk to me about anything even remotely political or controversial because I challenge her on it every time.

I was visiting her a few weeks ago due to another family member having a stroke when I saw the Epoch Times laying around her living room. I was feeling distraught about it but didn't bring it up at the time. I've since written her a letter, because I need to talk to her about it and I'm concerned for her mental health, but I'm honestly terrified of having this conversation.

I appreciate that this group exists. I've just had a weight on me for weeks now, but I'm comforted slightly knowing others are going through similar things with other family members."
